info.author: Luke Newcomb
classifiers: License :: OSI Approved :: GNU General Public License v3 (GPLv3)
info.description:
# kobjectlib
A small repository that just contains the Python library for reading and writing KerbalObject files for use with the KerbalAssembler and KerbalLinker

Tested using Python 3.6.9

This is a Python module that is not executable, and should be included in other projects that would like to use the KerbalObject file format. For example the projects [kobjdump](https://github.com/etherealfryingpan/kobjdump "kobjdump's GitHub") and [klinker](https://github.com/etherealfryingpan/kerbal-klinker "klinker's GitHub")

---

This package can either be used by downloading the source and including the folder in your project, or by installing it from PyPi:

`pip3 install kobjectlib`

The most important part of the project is definitely kobjectlib.KOFile, which is a class that represents an entire KerbalObject file.

From there, one can read a KO file:

```
from kobjectlib import KOFile

contents = None

with open('object.ko', 'rb') as fh:
    contents = fh.read()

kobj = KOFile.read(contents)
```

And then possibly write it again:

```
# ...continued...

kobj_bytes = kobj.generate()

with open('object2.ko', 'wb') as fh:
    fh.write(kobj_bytes)
```

All of the code is commented, so it should be okay to understand.
info.name: kobjectlib
info.summary: Python library for reading and writing KerbalObject files
info.html_description:
kobjectlib

A small repository that just contains the Python library for reading and writing KerbalObject files for use with the KerbalAssembler and KerbalLinker

Tested using Python 3.6.9

This is a Python module that is not executable, and should be included in other projects that would like to use the KerbalObject file format. For example the projects kobjdump and klinker

This package can either be used by downloading the source and including the folder in your project, or by installing it from PyPi:

pip3 install kobjectlib

The most important part of the project is definitely kobjectlib.KOFile, which is a class that represents an entire KerbalObject file.

From there, one can read a KO file:

from kobjectlib import KOFile

contents = None

with open('object.ko', 'rb') as fh:
    contents = fh.read()

kobj = KOFile.read(contents)

And then possibly write it again:

# ...continued...

kobj_bytes = kobj.generate()

with open('object2.ko', 'wb') as fh:
    fh.write(kobj_bytes)

All of the code is commented, so it should be okay to understand.
